subject: Re: [junit] Another question on assertEquals()
msgSnippet: I am jumping in on this one late (haven t followed the whole thread) but you need to implement equals() (and consequently hashCode()) on your object to be able
messageBody:
I am jumping in on this one late (haven't followed the whole thread) but
you need to implement equals() (and consequently hashCode()) on your
object to be able to compare the fields. Your object should take care
of determining whether 2 floats that it is hanging onto are equal.

Jason

Anna Skawinska wrote:
> Hi,
>
>
> comparing two floats is only possible, if you provide the method
> with accuracy passed as the third argument:
> assertEquals(double expected, double actual, double delta)
>
> The question is, how do I compare two objects which contain floats,
> tables of floats or composed objects, which in turn contain floats? Do
> I have to recurse through the inner fields, comparing them with the
> overloaded method appropriate for floats?
>
> Or am I wrong thinking the assertion doesn't work because of the
> float composition and it's probably the fault of my objects, which are
> not de facto equal?
>
>
> Anna Skawinska
